review.title: Proportional Representation in Vote Streams
review.abstract: We consider elections where the voters come one at a time, in a streaming fashion, and devise space-efficient algorithms which identify an approximate winning committee with respect to common multiwinner proportional representation voting rules; specifically, we consider the Approval-based and the Borda-based variants of both the Chamberlin-- ourant rule and the Monroe rule. We complement our algorithms with lower bounds. Somewhat surprisingly, our results imply that, using space which does not depend on the number of voters it is possible to efficiently identify an approximate representative committee of fixed size over vote streams with huge number of voters.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 2.08 862v 1 [cs.G T] February 28, 2017We look at elections where voters come one by one and develop space-saving algorithms that identify an approximate winning committee in terms of the general proportional representation rules for multiple winners; in particular, we look at variants of the Chamberlin Courant Rule and the Monroe Rule based on admission and the Borda Rule. We add lower limits to our algorithms. Somewhat surprisingly, our results imply that it is possible to efficiently identify an approximate representative committee of fixed size with an enormous number of voters using space that does not depend on the number of voters. sections.heading: 1.1 Related Work
sections.text: The two most related works to our work are two works by Bhattacharyya and Dey [3, 10]. The first work [3] provides an analysis of the spatial complexity of streaming algorithms for some voting rules for individual winners. The second work [10] provides an analysis of the number of samples sufficient to approximately calculate the winner according to different voting rules for individual winners, and is important to our work as our algorithms are based on random samples. Another related work is that of Filtser and Talmon [13], which provides efficient protocols for determining the winner in distributed streams.
